entry.summary:
← Older revision Revision as of 22:30, 30 May 2019

Line 1: Line 1:
−
Fan of Touhou official games and also fangames. Top-ranked non-JP player in [[Touhou Koubutou|Touhou Kobuto V: Burst Battle]] (at least in Score Attack and Arcade modes) who tries to support the game in his spare time~ (Kobuto's gameplay is a lot better than people have given it credit for! It's a competitive fighter that wasn't presented that way when it was localized. It deserves more tournaments than [https://challonge.com/games/touhou-kobuto-v-burst-battle/tournaments.html this], hahaha.)
+
Fan of Touhou official games and also fangames. Top-ranked non-JP player in [[Touhou Koubutou|Touhou Kobuto V: Burst Battle]] (at least in Score Attack and Arcade modes) who tries to support the game in his spare time~ (Kobuto's gameplay is a lot better than people have given it credit for! It's a competitive fighter that wasn't presented that way when it was localized. For [http://www.vgchartz.com/game/194041/touhou-kobuto-v-burst-battle/ a game that, according to vgchartz, sold] roughly as much as [http://www.vgchartz.com/game/220338/blazblue-cross-tag-battle/?region=All a fighting game on EVO's main stage twice], it deserves more tournaments than [https://challonge.com/games/touhou-kobuto-v-burst-battle/tournaments.html this], hahaha.)
  
 
Further information about the gameplay section of the Touhou Kobuto V article can be found on the article's [[Talk:Touhou Koubutou|Talk page]].

entry.title: Shrine Maiden
entry.summary:
← Older revision Revision as of 02:50, 30 May 2019
(3 intermediate revisions by the same user not shown)
Line 1: Line 1:
−
The term {{nihongo|'''shrine maiden'''|巫女|miko}}, also called a '''shaman''', refers specifically to altar girls of the [[Shinto]] religion. They live and work in a [[wikipedia:Shinto shrine|Shinto shrine]] (a "jinja" in Japanese). Shrine maidens are generally virgins and take various rites of purity and chastity, and undergo various forms of physical and mental training. They also practice sealing and purification rituals, which are highly form-based and symbolic, and are used to bless, purify, or exorcise [[vengeful spirit]]s.
+
The term {{nihongo|'''shrine maiden'''|巫女|miko}}, also called a '''shaman''', refers specifically to altar girls of the [[Shinto]] religion. They live and work in a [[wikipedia:Shinto shrine|Shinto shrine]]. Shrine maidens are generally virgins and take various rites of purity and chastity, and undergo various forms of physical and mental training. They also practice sealing and purification rituals, which are highly form-based and symbolic, and are used to bless, purify, or exorcise [[vengeful spirit]]s.
  
−
A shrine maiden's main tool, or possibly simply the most popular one, is a stick with [[wikipedia:Shide (Shinto)|elaborately folded paper]] on the end, known as a "[[gohei]]". The name of Reimu's gohei is the "purification rod" ({{lang|ja|御祓い棒}}). Other common tools are small rectangular papers used for sealing, called "[[wikipedia:O-fuda|o-fuda]]"; these are elaborately painted with various mystical symbols and rites of sealing.
+
A shrine maiden's iconic ritual implement is a wand with [[wikipedia:Shide (Shinto)|elaborately folded paper]] on the end, known as a ''[[gohei]]''. Reimu's gohei is called the ''purification rod'' ({{lang|ja|御祓い棒}}). Other common tools are small, rectangular paper amulets called ''[[wikipedia:O-fuda|o-fuda]]'', on which the names of gods are calligraphically inscribed.
  
 
==Characters under this Bestiary==
 
==Characters under this Bestiary==

entry.title: Tenshi Hinanawi
entry.summary:
← Older revision Revision as of 02:02, 30 May 2019
Line 137: Line 137:
 
*Many of the mythological references Tenshi makes are those to the {{nihongo||天部|Tenbu|Deva in sanskrit}}. In Buddhism, Deva are humans that have achieved enlightenment, and in ''[[Scarlet Weather Rhapsody]]'', Tenshi mentions the five signs of death of a Deva. Devas are also known to be mortal in Buddhism, living long lives, but still remaining part of the circle of life and death. This too, ties in with the events in Komachi's scenario in the game. Considering earlier references by [[ZUN]] to the Tennin (such as [[Perfect Cherry Blossom/Spell Cards/Stage 5#Spell Card 085|several of Youmu's spell cards]] in ''[[Perfect Cherry Blossom]]''), both Tenbu and Tennin are the same in [[Gensokyo]].
 
*Many of the mythological references Tenshi makes are those to the {{nihongo||天部|Tenbu|Deva in sanskrit}}. In Buddhism, Deva are humans that have achieved enlightenment, and in ''[[Scarlet Weather Rhapsody]]'', Tenshi mentions the five signs of death of a Deva. Devas are also known to be mortal in Buddhism, living long lives, but still remaining part of the circle of life and death. This too, ties in with the events in Komachi's scenario in the game. Considering earlier references by [[ZUN]] to the Tennin (such as [[Perfect Cherry Blossom/Spell Cards/Stage 5#Spell Card 085|several of Youmu's spell cards]] in ''[[Perfect Cherry Blossom]]''), both Tenbu and Tennin are the same in [[Gensokyo]].
 
*One of her color palettes in ''[[Touhou Hisoutensoku]]'' resembles [[Renko Usami]].
 
*One of her color palettes in ''[[Touhou Hisoutensoku]]'' resembles [[Renko Usami]].
−
*Additionally, one of her color palettes in [[Antimony of Common Flowers]] resembles [[Iku Nagae]].
+
*Additionally, one of her color palettes in [[Antinomy of Common Flowers]] resembles [[Iku Nagae]].
 
*[[ZUN]] designed the official shirt for the 2013 [[wikipedia:Anime Weekend Atlanta|Anime Weekend Atlanta]] convention. Tenshi appears on the shirt because the US state of [[wikipedia:Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] is known as the ''Peach State'', which is appropriate.
 
*[[ZUN]] designed the official shirt for the 2013 [[wikipedia:Anime Weekend Atlanta|Anime Weekend Atlanta]] convention. Tenshi appears on the shirt because the US state of [[wikipedia:Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] is known as the ''Peach State'', which is appropriate.
 
*In the heaven [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Journey_to_the_West Journey to the west] describes the only available food to eat were peaches and they seemed to have the same effect on those who ate it to the point where they were the raw material for the making of the immortality elixir.
 
*In the heaven [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Journey_to_the_West Journey to the west] describes the only available food to eat were peaches and they seemed to have the same effect on those who ate it to the point where they were the raw material for the making of the immortality elixir.

entry.title: Kasen Ibaraki
entry.summary:
← Older revision Revision as of 02:02, 30 May 2019
Line 144: Line 144:
 
After Kasen came down from the mountain in the present day, Yukari assumed Kasen was always "on her side" and that Kasen's actions were intended to help Yukari's ideals. Kasen finally got fed up by the time of Wild and Horned Hermit Chapter 35 and angrily informed Yukari that she wasn't on her side. This caused Yukari a brief visible moment of distress before she regained her composure, but she also stated she would wait as long as it takes for Kasen to come to her side.
 
After Kasen came down from the mountain in the present day, Yukari assumed Kasen was always "on her side" and that Kasen's actions were intended to help Yukari's ideals. Kasen finally got fed up by the time of Wild and Horned Hermit Chapter 35 and angrily informed Yukari that she wasn't on her side. This caused Yukari a brief visible moment of distress before she regained her composure, but she also stated she would wait as long as it takes for Kasen to come to her side.
  
−
Kasen's dream self in [[Antimony of Common Flowers]] calls Yukari a coward who gets others to do her work for her because she's too scared to do it herself.  As dream selves are unrestrained exaggerations of the real being, it is uncertain how much of this reflects Kasen's actual view of Yukari, but from Doremy's explanation of dream selves in Reisen's scenario, it does mean Kasen's normal feelings fall along those lines at least somewhat.
+
Kasen's dream self in [[Antinomy of Common Flowers]] calls Yukari a coward who gets others to do her work for her because she's too scared to do it herself.  As dream selves are unrestrained exaggerations of the real being, it is uncertain how much of this reflects Kasen's actual view of Yukari, but from Doremy's explanation of dream selves in Reisen's scenario, it does mean Kasen's normal feelings fall along those lines at least somewhat.
  
 
;[[Okina Matara]]
 
;[[Okina Matara]]

A '''Yuki-onna''' ({{lang|ja|雪女}}) is the Japanese word for snow woman. They are a spirit or a [[youkai]], associated with winter and snowstorms. Yuki-onna are often described wearing a white kimono (or any clothes resembling such), or naked, with only their hair and face standing out.

A {{nihongo|'''Yuki-onna'''|雪女||"snow-woman"}} is a spirit or a [[youkai]] associated with winter and snowstorms. It is said in some legends to be the spirit of an individual who has perished in the snow and cold. Yuki-onna are often described wearing a white kimono (or any clothes resembling such), or naked, with only their hair and face standing out. Despite their inhuman beauty, they are hostile to [[human]]s and kill them unsuspectingly.

entry.title: Talk:Touhou Wiki
entry.summary:
‎Music Titles and Potential Redundancies

← Older revision Revision as of 21:49, 29 May 2019
Line 142: Line 142:
 
:::::::::I wasn't gonna weigh in on this originally but I thought I might just to see if I can offer a little insight on what seems to be an endless back and forth discussion. First and foremost, this is a wiki. We primarily record all things canon to the series. We should, ideally, preserve the titles no matter how redundant because, in the end, ZUN wrote them that way. But, we have leeway with translation. We don't have to have "Sleeping Terror ~ Sleeping Terror". Why not "Dormant Horror ~ Sleeping Terror", for example? That's a valid translation and it gets rid of a ridiculous title repetition. Why not? Same thing was done for Phantom Band, Casket of Star, and Luna Dial ("月時計　～ ルナ・ダイアル" is just the repetition of [moon]+[timepiece]). In order to remove hilarious redundancy, I propose that new translations be made. "End of the World ~ World's End" (世界の果て refers to the edge of the world; Pandemonium is canonically at the edge of Makai, according to Shiki) could be "Edge of Space ~ World's End" as 世界 can mean "realm" or "dimension" and Makai is, based on what little we know of it, no orb-shaped planet. These are just suggestions of course. If this idea is implemented we could always have a vote on titles. But, yeah. I believe that giving alternative translations to these titles is the perfect middle ground to outright removing them or keeping a ridiculously redundant title. Hopefully I don't sound too crazy making a suggestion like this. It's always an option.

But, we have leeway with translation. We don't have to have "Sleeping Terror ~ Sleeping Terror". Why not "Dormant Horror ~ Sleeping Terror", for example? That's a valid translation and it gets rid of a ridiculous title repetition. Why not? In order to remove hilarious redundancy, I propose that new translations be made. "End of the World ~ World's End" (世界の果て refers to the edge of the world; Pandemonium is canonically at the edge of Makai, according to Shiki) could be "Edge of Space ~ World's End" as 世界 can mean "realm" or "dimension" and Makai is, based on what little we know of it, no orb-shaped planet. :::::::::—[[User:Ennin|Ennin]] ([[User talk:Ennin|talk]]) 01:51, 28 May 2019 (UTC)

entry.title: Talk:Legacy of Lunatic Kingdom/Music
entry.summary:
‎The

← Older revision Revision as of 09:59, 29 May 2019
Line 106: Line 106:
 
::And now on to "Pierrot of the Star-Spangled Banner". That's fine the way it is. First off, ZUN uses ピエロ and not ザ・ピエロ (but don't focus on that part). Secondly, look at her name. It's Clownpiece. クラウンピース. クラウン. If ZUN intended for "clown" to be in the title then he would have used クラウン. And, yes, of course I know that "piero" is just the Japanese way of saying clown. But ZUN obviously wanted it there. And yes, Pierrot is a pantomime character. But literally who uses the word in that way anymore besides scholars and those in the art? In modern times "pierrot" (in English) is synonymous with "clown" and is literally the first thing an average person would think of when they hear the word, not an archetype of classical French theatre. I can't imagine anyone getting confused besides people who are somehow more familiar with pantomime and unaware of Japanese naming conventions. Anyone who has been interested in anime/manga/Japanese video games/etc can tell you that "pierrot" means "clown". Hell, the first thing that comes up on YouTube when you search up "pierrot" is a ''Vocaloid'' song. Who are we pandering to here? People who have never come into contact with the word aside from being familiar with relatively obscure French performing arts? I'm sorry but I find it a little far fetched to believe that people would have trouble with the word. Ever since LoLK was released and the title kept "pierrot" over clown, I have seen absolutely no one confused with it. Even if they didn't know what it meant before they sure do now thanks to Clownpiece. So, no, I do not think adding "the" to the title is necessary. The vast majority of people know that pierrot is a synonym for "clown". And I'm sorry but "Pierrette"??? This is a series where male gods and figures are portrayed as female. Miko is still a prince and Satono/Mai are still douji. Apologies if this is a little preachy or ranty but I am inclined to make sure that I explain myself thoroughly. And sorry for taking quite a while to respond, I've been quite the busy bee lately.
 
::And now on to "Pierrot of the Star-Spangled Banner". That's fine the way it is. First off, ZUN uses ピエロ and not ザ・ピエロ (but don't focus on that part). Secondly, look at her name. It's Clownpiece. クラウンピース. クラウン. If ZUN intended for "clown" to be in the title then he would have used クラウン. And, yes, of course I know that "piero" is just the Japanese way of saying clown. But ZUN obviously wanted it there. And yes, Pierrot is a pantomime character. But literally who uses the word in that way anymore besides scholars and those in the art? In modern times "pierrot" (in English) is synonymous with "clown" and is literally the first thing an average person would think of when they hear the word, not an archetype of classical French theatre. I can't imagine anyone getting confused besides people who are somehow more familiar with pantomime and unaware of Japanese naming conventions. Anyone who has been interested in anime/manga/Japanese video games/etc can tell you that "pierrot" means "clown". Hell, the first thing that comes up on YouTube when you search up "pierrot" is a ''Vocaloid'' song. Who are we pandering to here? People who have never come into contact with the word aside from being familiar with relatively obscure French performing arts? I'm sorry but I find it a little far fetched to believe that people would have trouble with the word. Ever since LoLK was released and the title kept "pierrot" over clown, I have seen absolutely no one confused with it. Even if they didn't know what it meant before they sure do now thanks to Clownpiece. So, no, I do not think adding "the" to the title is necessary. The vast majority of people know that pierrot is a synonym for "clown". And I'm sorry but "Pierrette"??? This is a series where male gods and figures are portrayed as female. Miko is still a prince and Satono/Mai are still douji. Apologies if this is a little preachy or ranty but I am inclined to make sure that I explain myself thoroughly. And sorry for taking quite a while to respond, I've been quite the busy bee lately.
 
::—[[User:Ennin|Ennin]] ([[User talk:Ennin|talk]]) 11:52, 28 May 2019 (UTC)
 
::—[[User:Ennin|Ennin]] ([[User talk:Ennin|talk]]) 11:52, 28 May 2019 (UTC)
 +
 +
:::No need to apologise – thoroughness is good, and I think you raise some very good points there. Take all the time you need. Discussing this clarifies my own understanding, and it makes me think about grammar in an entirely different way!
 +
 +
:::I think something your ‘sealed gods’ example makes clear is that we don’t really need ‘the’ when the sentence includes a plural. When I read ‘let’s visit sealed gods’, I see it as meaning “Let’s visit a bunch of sealed gods” or “let’s visit sealed gods [as opposed to unsealed gods]. There’s nothing specific in there, kind of like “let’s climb tall mountains.” Basically, if the title was “Reversed Wheels of Fortune” I’d have no issue. Plurals, for some mysterious reason, seem exempt from this.
 +
 +
:::In regards to your other examples, ‘Lunar Dial’ works fine, functioning in the same way as ‘Space Shuttle’ or ‘Lunar Rover’. ‘Cemetery of Onbashira’ is a little vaguer, but the fragmentation works fine when you consider things/titles like “Garden of Eden” or “Game of Thrones”. In this case, the noun comes first so it feels more natural.
 +
 +
:::I almost feel like we’re on the verge of working out some rules for when we should use ‘the’. I wish I had something more concrete than “The Reversed Wheel of Fortune” sounds more natural than “Reversed Wheel of Fortune”... Like, it’s the difference between “Great Wall of China” and “The Great Wall of China”. I can’t express that very well...
 +
 +
:::As for Clownpiece, none of the points you raised explain the discrepancy between ピエロ恐怖症 being translated as “fear of clowns”, and 星条旗のピエロ being translated as “Pierrot of the Star-Spangled Banner”. Both use exactly the same katakana, and both appear really close to each other. ZUN could have used 道化恐怖症, but he used ピエロ恐怖症 instead.
 +
 +
:::I think the answer is that, in Japanese, if you want a cool-sounding foreign loanword to use instead of 道化 (douke - clown) you have two choices: クラウン and ピエロ. Neither of them have the same baggage because they both sound equally foreign and unique, and both now mean exactly the same thing. This isn’t the case in English – I think we pretty much kept going with clown because we didn’t need to import another word. If anything, we’re more likely to use jester instead.
 +
 +
:::In short, I think ピエロ should be translated as ‘clown’ because, regardless of whether people are or are not confused by ‘pierrot’, ピエロ functions as ‘clown’ in the text. We chose to translate ピエロ恐怖症 as ‘fear of clowns’ for a reason, and I think that same reasoning should inform our decision to translate 星条旗のピエロ as ‘Clown of the Star-Spangled Banner’.
 +
 +
:::I feel like there might be more important issues to debate, but this is pretty fun. Sorry for taking up your time with this! [[User:Biggest Dreamer|Biggest Dreamer]] ([[User talk:Biggest Dreamer|talk]]) 09:59, 29 May 2019 (UTC)

entry.title: Eika Ebisu
entry.summary:
‎Design: References to jellyfish, most specifically immortal jellyfish ''Turritopsis dohrnii''

← Older revision Revision as of 03:55, 29 May 2019
Line 35: Line 35:
  
 
===Design===
 
===Design===
 +
Her color palette seems to be based off –to an extent– of ''[[Wikipedia:Turritopsis dohrnii|Turritopsis dohrnii]]'' (commonly known as the ''immortal jellyfish''), a species of small, biologically immortal jellyfish found in the Mediterranean Sea and in the waters of Japan. It is one of the few known cases of animals capable of reverting completely to a sexually immature, colonial stage after having reached sexual maturity as a solitary individual. The liner notes for her boss theme ''Jelly Stone'' make a reference to jellyfish – probably this specific species in particular.

| ja  =昔は「写メール」っていう携帯電話の機能があって、それをもじって「射命丸」にしました。「文々。新聞」は、字面は「モーニング娘。」みたいに記号で遊ぶのが流行ってたから。読み方はゲームライターの「ブンブン丸」さんから。いろいろなものをパロディとして詰め込んでますね。新聞記者って他のキャラをまとめられる、どこに接点があっても不思議じゃないキャラが生まれて、ようやく作品を超えて「東方」が拡がった。そういう意味では特別なキャラ。
 
| ja  =昔は「写メール」っていう携帯電話の機能があって、それをもじって「射命丸」にしました。「文々。新聞」は、字面は「モーニング娘。」みたいに記号で遊ぶのが流行ってたから。読み方はゲームライターの「ブンブン丸」さんから。いろいろなものをパロディとして詰め込んでますね。新聞記者って他のキャラをまとめられる、どこに接点があっても不思議じゃないキャラが生まれて、ようやく作品を超えて「東方」が拡がった。そういう意味では特別なキャラ。
−
| en  =
+
| en  =Cell phones back in the day had a "photo mail" function-- ''"sha-meeru"''-- and I named her "Shameimaru" as a play on that. The "maru" in "Bunbunmaru Newspaper" comes from a trend of playing with punctuation around that time, like with "[[wikipedia:Morning_Musume|Morning Musume.]]", and the title's pronunciation comes from the video game journalist "Bunbun Maru". She's got various parodies like that stuffed into her. Since she's a journalist, she made for a character who can easily bring the others together, and have points of connection with just about anyone without it feeling strange. That helped Touhou finally expand out beyond each individual work, so in that sense she's a pretty special character.
 
}}
 
}}

entry.title: Gensou Shoujo Taisen/Story Mode (You)/Stage 31
entry.summary:
Created page with "==Stage 31: Cherry Blossom Barrier Above the Clouds Part 2== ===Victory Conditions=== *Defeat Ran. ===Defeat Conditions=== *All allies are defeated. ===Bonus WP Conditions===..."

New page

==Stage 31: Cherry Blossom Barrier Above the Clouds Part 2==
===Victory Conditions===
*Defeat Ran.
===Defeat Conditions===
*All allies are defeated.
===Bonus WP Conditions===
*Activate Ran's first spell card within 3 turns.

===Stage Data===
Time: Day

====Starting Units====
{|border="1" cellpadding="5" cellspacing="0"
|-
!Ally Unit
|Free Slots: 20 & Cost Allowance: 30.0
|-
!Enemy Unit
|Ran Yakumo
|-
!Enemy Unit
|Chen
|-
!Enemy Unit
|Zenki
|-
!Enemy Unit
|Gouki
|-
!Enemy Unit
|Kedama *4
|-
!Enemy Unit
|Crow Youkai *9
|-
!Enemy Unit
|Strong Kedama *5
|-
|}

===Events===

*All enemies start with +10 power.
*When Chen is defeated, Ran will cast Strike and Spirit on herself.

===Stage Walkthrough===

*Like in Chapter 21, your units are stuck in a pincer strike - you've got Ran, Chen, and a bunch of kedama on the "front", as well as a whole murder of crows, led by Zenki and Gouki, at your back. All of them will move on turn 1, and the bonus WP condition requires you to take out Ran's first lifebar at a very fast pace. All in all, this is easily the second most difficult stage of the game (after chapter 21), and you should expect to struggle at least a little here. Try to bring Elly to the map with Tile Danmaku equipped, as it will become very handy.
*On paper, the easiest way to achieve the bonus WP condition is to simply bum rush Chen and try to take her out on turn 2, then activate Ran's spell card on turn 3. However, Zenki and Gouki will catch up to your characters, and they do have Shikigami (Ran) which gives them regeneration if they get close to Ran, making them more difficult to take out in that case (especially since your army will be struggling to deal with Ran's cards, the first of which is a MAP). As such, the best way to approach this chapter is to send one or two strong units to deal with the crows, while everyone else rush Chen and Ran. Alternatively, if you don't care about the bonus WP condition, having everyone retreat toward the crows and take them out, then deal with Ran as she approach is probably the easiest method to simply beat the chapter.
*Zenki and Gouki have higher HP than last time, and as usual they will stick close to support each other, plus Gouki can support defend for the crows as well. Since Gouki is going to be taking hits anyways, it's best to take him down first, then focus on the crows that are launching danmaku.
*Since the entire map is the air, Chen doesn't get to use her S on ground, which mean she's a bit easier to hit than she was in chapter 29. However, she can use Bakeneko "Chen" right off the bat, and she still got her double image, plus regeneration due to being near Ran. Luckily, she's still rather frail and easy to kill, especialy if Ran isn't nearby to support defend her. Try to kill her on turn 2, so you don't end up having Ran cast Strike while having her first spellcard out - it's a MAP attack and it will murder your Real-type characters if she gets to use it while having Strike on.
*Ran herself also has double image, an equipment that raises her mobility by 20, and extremely strong stats. She's difficult to hit and has very punishing retaliations, and you've got a very tight time limit on taking out her lifebars if you want the WP bonus. You've got a few options to deal with double image - try to lower her power with Rumia's Daunt, then hitting her with Shizuha's Loneliness to keep it low, or have Hina hit her with Bad Fortune (though Hina has to hit to begin with), or simply override it with Strike and Attune. Before taking her out first lifebar, if you have Elly with Tile Danmaku, then make sure she still gets a turn after the spell card activation, and get everyone who don't want to get hit at least 5 tiles away from Ran. If not, then just try to surround Ran with a few sturdy characters, or at least get your frail characters as far away from Ran as possible, and perhaps with a defensive spirit at ready just in case.
*Ultimate Buddhism is a post-movement MAP that hits an area around Ran, and the manji sign part of the damnaku prevents entry. With the extremely tight time limit it's unlikely that you have time to activate the card and capture it in one turn. If you have Elly ready to immobilize her, then you can get out of range, let her MAP whiff, then move in next turn for the kill. Otherwise, you're just going to have to cast defensive spirits as much as possible, then pray that she doesn't find a spot that messes you up too much. If you somehow still haven't killed Chen at this point, then leave her alone - you do not want Ran to cast Strike on a MAP attack.
*Kokkuri-san's Contract puts up a field that greatly increases all of Ran's stats and lowers your units' evasion, making battling Ran a daunting aspect if you don't bomb away the field. However, Ran can at least only hit one character on her own turn, so if you can survive her counterattacks with defensive spirits, then taking her down should be fairly routine. As long as you can get past her evasion and Double Image, the battle is about as good as won at this point.
----
{{Gensou_Shoujo_Taisen/Stages}}
